utterances: Yeah.
That...
But you're right about boomers that there seems to be more of a willingness to re-explore...
All right.
...to re-examine, to reconnect and to be diverse in what they're interested in.
I want to get a few more of them on.
Thank you for calling, Rez.
I appreciate it.
Thanks.
Take care.
Thanks for calling.
Bye-bye.
So, Ken, tell me this, what are these communities doing to approach--you heard Ken say that these maybe real estate guys in their 30s maybe don't quite get it is that's going to appeal to boomers.
What are they doing, the ones who are successful?
Well, let's keep in mind that the oldest boomer now is 60 and the average retirement age is 64, so this is something that we're just beginning to see.
It's sort of like popcorn that's in the microwave.
It's not quite popping yet.
It's a little bit like if I could take you to Levittown, Long Island, in 1945 before suburbia went crazy.
But here's what they're doing.
What you're seeing more and more in magazines is that communities and areas we--states even, are beginning to place ads out saying, `Great place to have fun.
Great place to adventure--have an adventure.
Low crime.
Wonderful housing.
Low taxes.
No state taxes,' which are very subtle ways of trying to attract that new 60-, 65-year-old.
Like...
Though it sounds very much like the old way, I mean, you know, a nice, soft life, the sun is shining, the taxes are low.
Not talking about the things Rez was talking about which is a lot of vitality, the urban life, that sort of thing.
Exactly.
And what you're seeing in some ads, and frankly a lot of Web sites, is the beginnings of promotions that talk more about culture, theater, arts, bookstores, classes.
You know, if you live in this town you can take free classes at the university.
If you live in this town, you get free access to the health spa, the gym.
If you live in this town, you know, we've got the greatest community center in the region.
And the key to it is not to focus on old or aging, 'cause that's a total turnoff to boomers.
We are talking about that next generation of retirees and how they spend their golden years.
How about you?

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Frank Stasio in Washington.
We're talking about the changing face of retirement.

Cities and towns around the country hoping to cash in on the potential economic boom that older residents may offer, and I'm talking with Ken Dychtwald who will scold me again for using that `old' word.
He's a gerontologist and CEO of AgeWave, a think tank that studies aging trends.
We're taking your calls at (800) 989-8255.
I think we ought to do that right now.
Connie's on the line from Sioux Falls, South Dakota.
Hi, Connie.
Well, hi there.
How's it going with you?
Well, it's going great and isn't it great to be a baby boomer.
Yeah, at times.
So what are you doing?
I'm assuming that you're thinking about retirement, on your way?
Well, I'm 56 and have been retired for about a year and my husband is 61 and he's been retired for about three years.

We spend most of our winters in the South because we're from South Dakota and you're talking about, you know, these great things that people are looking for baby boomers to come and settle in their areas.
And are there publications out there?
For an example, South Dakota has no income tax--state income tax.
We probably will relocate in the next couple of years to a warmer climate.
Where can a person hone in on these benefits that are out there for the baby boomers since we have all this money to spend?
All right.
Ken, any ideas?
Yeah.

Let me mention a couple of examples and then I'll--I'm not here to promote the book, but in my book I give nothing but lots of Web sites that you can find, if you're in the mind to explore different places to live.
And there's about a thousand Web sites up there right now that can show you why they want you to move to their town.

But there's also another thing going on, which is about 10 percent of boomers are thinking of buying a second home and it doesn't--it's not just the rich boomers; it's people who want to have several locations.
There's a business called cruiseshipcondos.com for people who want to float around the world non-stop.
Sunset Hall in Los Angeles bills itself as a home for free-thinking older adults.
ElderSpirit is a residence for artists in Manhattan.
San Francisco is developing a gay community for low-income people called Open House.
You know, I think the people...
You know what else?
Ken, you could go to Tyler, Texas.
Tyler, Texas...
Well, I'm going to go to Tom Mullins now, who's...
Please.
Certified retirement community.
Right.
Right.
...actually from Tyler, Texas.
I want you to stay with us.
Tyler, Texas, actually has 10 reasons to retire in Tyler on its Web site.
It's not the only thing that they've done to attract retirees.
Tom Mullins is president and CEO of the Tyler Area Chamber of Commerce and joins us from his office in Tyler, Texas.
Thanks for being with us, Tom.
Well, thank you for having me.
I appreciate it.
Ten reasons to retire in Tyler.
Number one?

Low cost of living, great housing options, warm climate, medical services, recreational opportunities, fine dining, cultural attractions, financial services, educational opportunities and spiritual and religious options.
Now it sounds like those are good reasons for anybody to come to Tyler.
Are you targeting your message at all to people who might be closing in on retirement?
Yeah, we are.
We've been targeting retirees for the last 10 years and we have special mail-out package when people call in.
And we're finding out that retirees are being very sophisticated about doing a site search, almost like a company looking for a new site.
They analyze states and then they narrow it down to a certain number of cites and then they make a site visit and then they make a choice.
And why are you so interested in retirees?
Well, they're a new source of income.
What we're trying to do is bring new revenue.
We don't want to become just a retirement community, but we want retirees to be a part of the overall economic puzzle.
We still have a strong manufacturing and distribution and tourism base and medical and retail and all those things.
But retirees bring new dollars in, what we call mailbox income.
They spend 90 percent of that income in the local economy, and they're retiring younger and younger and they really get involved.
They become volunteers, they get active in the community and they want lots of recreational opportunities and activities to engage in.
All right .
Well, Tom, stay with us.
